---
  title: Categorical vs Continuous!
---





<div id="graphs-to-compare-categorical-and-continuous-data" class="section level1">
<h1>Graphs to Compare Categorical and Continuous Data</h1>
<p>Many times we need to compare categorical and continuous data. We will consider the following <code>geom_</code> functions to do this:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>geom_jitter</code> adds random noise</li>
<li><code>geom_boxplot</code> boxplots</li>
<li><code>geom_violin</code> compact version of density</li>
</ul>
<div id="jitter-plot" class="section level3">
<h3>Jitter Plot</h3>
<p>In when you group continuous data into different categories, it can be hard to see where all of the data lies since many points can lie right on top of each other. The jitter plot will and a small amount of random noise to the data and allow it to spread out and be more visible.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>ggplot(data, aes(x=carrier, y= dep_delay)) +
        geom_jitter()</code></pre>
<p>We can add this as another layer just like we did with <code>geom_point()</code> Below you can see the outcome of this code:</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
<div id="boxplot" class="section level3">
<h3>Boxplot</h3>
<p>Boxplots are one of the most commonly used statistics plots to display continuous data. It is extremely useful to evaluate the distribution of a continuous random variable across multiple groups. We can easily make this by adding a <code>geom_boxplot()</code> layer:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>ggplot(data, aes(x=carrier, y= dep_delay)) + 
        geom_boxplot()</code></pre>
<p>As you can see as long as we know the <code>geom_</code> function that we wish to use, the rest comes by simply adding it as another layer. The above code leads to the graph below:</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
<div id="violin" class="section level3">
<h3>Violin</h3>
<p>Another plot to help display continuous data among different categories. In order to deal with multiple data points lying in a close area, the violin plot is wider at points where the data is bulked. We can simply code this with a <code>geom_violin()</code> layer:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>ggplot(data, aes(x=carrier, y= dep_delay)) + 
        geom_violin()</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
</div>




</div>
